body:
confirmed with current main, python 3.8 windows.

Problem looks like trouble with column renaming in the `Detrender`, combined with `sklearn`'s new input check on equal column names.
also fails with other forecasters instead of `PolynomialTrendForecaster`, so not a problem of that

The precise condition for failure is: a `pandas.Series` with a non-`None` name is being passed.
This works, if you take the name away from `y`:

```python
from sktime.forecasting.trend import PolynomialTrendForecaster
from sktime.transformations.series.detrend import Detrender
from sktime.forecasting.compose import TransformedTargetForecaster
from sktime.forecasting.naive import NaiveForecaster
from sktime.datasets import load_airline

y = load_airline()
y.name = None

trans_fc = TransformedTargetForecaster(
    [
        ("detrender", Detrender(forecaster=NaiveForecaster(strategy="last"))),
        ("forecaster", NaiveForecaster(strategy="last")),
    ]
)
trans_fc.fit(y)
trans_fc.predict(1)
```

We've previously had a number of issues where `pandas` would behave strangely when names were present in `Series` and passed to a `DataFrame` constructor.
Example:
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2604
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2607

& it has nothing to do with `sklearn`. The error occurs when conversion with unexpected variable names being produced hit some custom vectorization over variables in the `Detrender`.
I think that shouldn't really happen from a logic/content perspective, but is a separate issue and not the root of the bug.

issue.title: [BUG] attempted fix 1 to #2739 - keeping `pd.DataFrame` column name as `pd.Series` name after conversion

labels.name: bugfix
labels.description: Fixes a known bug or removes unintended behavior

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This is an attempted fix for #2739.

The fix is ensuring that, when converting a univariate `pd.DataFrame` to `pd.Series`, that the output `pd.Series` retains the  `pd.DataFrame` column name as `pd.Series` name.

Includes #2790 to check that we've solved #2739.

Unfortunately, this leads to breakage through `NaiveForecaster` which handles columns and names inconsistently.
That is addressed by a hard-fix of storing names/columns in `_fit` and overwriting whatever comes out of `_predict`.
At some point, we may want to untangle the nested, organically grown mess that is `NaiveForecaster` and clean it up, but until that day it at least has the right return format now.

issue.title: [BUG] attempted fix 2 to #2739 - removing `pd.Series` name as soon as seen

labels.name: bugfix
labels.description: Fixes a known bug or removes unintended behavior

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This is an attempted fix for #2739.

The fix is ensuring that, whenever seeing a `pd.Series`, its `name` is removed.

Includes #2790 to check that we've solved #2739.

body:
I think I understand the root cause.

The problem materializes under the following conditions:
* a `pd.Series` `y` is converted to `pd.DataFrame`, then back to `pd.Series`, then back to `pd.DataFrame`, by `convert` or `convert_to`
* the initial series `y` has a `name` attribute set
* there can be "pairing" through `converter_store`, but it is between the first two, not the last two conversions
* there can be transformations in-between the conversions, as long as they do not change column names or type

Then, what happens:
* after the first conversion, we have a `pd.DataFrame` with column name `y.name`
* after the last conversion, we have a `pd.DataFrame` with column name `0`

I.e., the name gets lost, and the column names are inconsistent between the two occurrences.

If, in addition, the conversions occur in a context where naming consistency is assumed (like in the pipeline above), an exception is raised.

I see two potential fixes, via the conversions:

* we do not allow `pd.Series` to have `name` at all. As soon as we encounter `pd.Series`, we remove the `name` attribute. Attempted here: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2788
* we ensure we keep the `name` attribute consistent throughout conversions, in this case we need to change the conversion from `pd.DataFrame` to `pd.Series` which eats the `name` away after conversion. Attempted here: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2789
Both seem to work, I'll add a test

issue.title: [ENH] forecasting pipeline test which triggers conversions and failure condition in #2739

labels.name: maintenance
labels.description: Continuous integration, unit testing & package distribution

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This adds a test that tests the specific pipeline from bug https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2739 .

The pipeline tests an integration condition which failed in #2739 due to subtle issues in handling `pd.Series.name`:

* a `pd.Series` `y` is converted to `pd.DataFrame`, then back to `pd.Series`, then back to `pd.DataFrame`, by `convert` or `convert_to`
* the initial series `y` has a `name` attribute set
* there can be "pairing" through `converter_store`, but it is between the first two, not the last two conversions
* there can be transformations in-between the conversions, as long as they do not change column names or type

Then, it happens that:
* after the first conversion, we have a `pd.DataFrame` with column name `y.name`
* after the last conversion, we have a `pd.DataFrame` with column name `0`

I.e., the name gets lost, and the column names are inconsistent between the two occurrences.

If the conversions occur in a context where naming consistency is assumed (like in the pipeline above), an exception is raised.

The context is created specifically by the pipeline in the test.

body: Hm, it looks like "keeping the `name` attribute" approach #2788 fixes *this* bug, but creates other bugs...

issue.title: [BUG] attempted fix 3 to #2739 - storing and restoring `pd.Series` name

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This is an attempted fix for #2739.

The fix is ensuring that, when converting `pd.Series` to `pd.DataFrame` and back, that the `name` is stored in the `converter_store` and restored at back-conversion.

body:
Fix no.3: doesn't break anything, but also doesn't fix this.
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2791

This fix to `NaiveForecaster` apparently fixes the problem:
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2793

issue.title: [BUG] add patch to ensure column/name preservation in `NaiveForecaster`

labels.name: bugfix
labels.description: Fixes a known bug or removes unintended behavior

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This PR adds a patch to `NaiveForecaster` which currently seem to handle `pd.DataFrame` column names and `pd.Series` names inconsistently, potentially losing them in the process of applying some of the strategies.

This is addressed by a hard-fix of storing names/columns in `_fit` and overwriting whatever comes out of `_predict`.
At some point, we may want to untangle the nested, organically grown mess that is `NaiveForecaster` and clean it up, but until that day at least outputs have the right return format now.

Includes #2790 to check that we've solved #2739.

body:
This is fixed now via #2793 and should work in 0.12.0.
It has also highlighted inconsistent handling of `pd.Series.name` which we need to think about carefully.
